thread.title: Trojans outlast Pineville in wild shootout
thread.title_full: Trojans outlast Pineville in wild shootout

title: Trojans outlast Pineville in wild shootout
text:
Trojans outlast Pineville in wild shootout Bret H. McCormick , bmccormick@thetowntalk.com, (318) 487-6431 3:18 a.m. CDT October 10, 2015 Buy Photo Pineville's Esdon Boyd (47, right) wraps up ASH's Tyler Clark (8, left) Friday. (Photo: Melinda Martinez/The Town Talk) Buy Photo 
PINEVILLE – Jarious Green and the Pineville Rebels shot every bullet in their arsenal Friday night. 
Matthew Beck and the ASH Trojans just had a little more ammunition. 
Green, the Rebels’ senior tailback, rushed for a career-high 278 yards after moving into the featured role as Pineville’s offense switched from the flexbone to the I formation. 
But Beck threw for 373 yards and five touchdowns, including two to sophomore Jorien Vallien, as Alexandria Senior High (5-1, 1-0 District 2-5A) pulled off a thrilling 49-40 victory in a Red River Rivalry contest that featured more than 1,000 combined yards of total offense. 
“We knew coming in that their offense was tremendous,” Pineville coach Robbie Martin said. “We knew we’d have to play our best game of the year offensively to score with them.” 
The Rebels (3-3, 0-1) actually compiled nearly 100 more yards of offense than the high-powered Trojans. Green shook off early injuries to his left knee and ankle, and thrived in his new role behind Landon King in the I formation. 
Green, who also played some snaps at quarterback in a new “Wild Rebel” formation, carried the ball 29 times for 278 yards and scored on touchdown runs of 8 and 80 yards. 
“That’s the best he’s ever run,” Martin said. “The offensive line did a great job. Everybody on the offense did a great job. … (Green) gutted it up and laid it on the line.” 
King, Pineville’s junior fullback, rushed for 97 yards and a score while senior quarterback Clayton Wider Jr. rushed for three scores and piled up 189 combined yards passing and rushing. 
But the Rebels’ 548 yards of total offense weren’t enough to overcome Beck and the outstanding Trojans’ offense of offensive coordinator Thomas Bachman. 
Beck, who has thrived in Bachman’s no-huddle, fast-paced offense, carved up the Rebels’ secondary, completing 25 of 36 passes and throwing touchdowns to four different receivers. 
Pineville led by 12 points (26-14) midway through the second quarter, but the Trojans battled back when senior running back Kyle Smith scored his second touchdown of the game and Beck found Vallien for a 54-yard touchdown with 12 seconds remaining. 
With the Trojans leading by two at the half, they came out and grabbed control in the third quarter. Beck threw touchdown passes to three different receivers – Andrew Bell, Tyler Clark and Suede Taylor – in the third quarter, the final one a back-breaking, 73-yard catch-and-run by Taylor (8-141, TD) that put ASH ahead 49-34. 
“I wasn’t throwing the best balls, but they made some great plays,” Beck said, deferring credit for his performance to his playmakers on the perimeter. 
ASH coach Sam Goodwin, however, saw the game a little differently. 
“You can’t outrun his arm,” Goodwin said. “The last play of the half (the 54-yard TD pass to Vallien, who had six catches for 122 yards) … not many guys can make that throw.” 
Two key special teams plays let the Rebels down. They missed their first extra point, a 35-yard attempt due to an unsportsmanlike conduct penalty, and a second missed PAT in the fourth quarter prevented Pineville from cutting the deficit to one score. 
After Wider’s third touchdown run cut the score to 49-40 with 8:54 remaining, the Rebels missed a second extra point and needed a touchdown and a field goal to win. They drove inside the 5-yard line late in the game, but facing fourth and goal, Martin elected to attempt a field goal. 
The snap was errant, and kicker Gavin Capehart’s pass for King in the end zone was batted down, as the Trojans ran out the clock for the victory. 
“It was a disappointing way to lose the game, but I couldn’t be more proud of the way we played,” Martin said. 
“It took everything we had to win the game,” Goodwin said. 
Beck, who improved to 2-2 in his career against the Rebels, said he was proud of the way his team fought for the victory. 
“We knew they would come out fighting (in the second half),” Beck said. “There was never a moment we thought they would lay down. There was never a moment we were going to lay down.” 
Goodwin said his team’s defense has given up too many big plays on the season. It cost the Trojans in their only loss against Leesville, and nearly cost them again Friday night. However, with their offense continually putting up 40-plus points per game, Goodwin said he likes his team’s chances moving forward. 
“I feel like we can compete with anybody,” Goodwin said. “I haven’t seen West Monroe, and that would be the one (that concerns me). If we can win this week, then we’ll worry about the next one after that.” Buy Photo 
Pineville's Landon King (32) gains yards against ASH Friday. (Photo: Melinda Martinez/The Town Talk) Buy Photo
